title: France avoids recession as economy returns to growth; UK house prices drop – business live
snippets:
Rolling coverage of the latest economic and financial news, including growth figures from across Europe

  • UK house prices fall but market ‘likely to pick up’ during summer
  • China manufacturing activity plummets amid Trump tariff war

France’s economy is likely to “flirt with stagnation” throughout the year, despite the small rebound in GDP in the last quarter, predicts Dutch bank ING.

Charlotte de Montpellier, ING’s senior economist for France and Switzerland, explains:

The additional customs duties in the US and their direct and indirect impact will delay the French economy’s rebound. We estimate that the direct effect of a permanent 10% import duty in the US on French GDP (via a reduction in exports) will be around -0.1%.

Adding to this are the effects of uncertainty, the global economic slowdown and more restrictive fiscal policy, all of which will weigh on French economic activity throughout the year. The cooling in the labour market is likely to limit the recovery in household consumption, and the savings rate is set to remain high.

Continue reading...
titles: France avoids recession as economy returns to growth; UK house prices drop – business live
summary: Recent economic updates reveal a downturn in UK house prices, expected to recover in the summer, while China's manufacturing activity significantly drops due to the ongoing Trump tariff war. Meanwhile, France's economy is predicted to barely grow, with ING forecasting a near stagnation affected by US import duties, global economic slowdown, and domestic factors. The direct impact of a 10% US import duty could reduce French GDP by -0.1%, compounded by high uncertainty, restrictive fiscal policy, and a cooling labour market, which may suppress household consumption and maintain a high savings ra
constructiveness_reason: The story is constructive as it provides useful insights into the economic trends in France and the UK, as well as the impact of US import duties on France's economy. It offers a deeper understanding of the global economic situation, even though the news is negative.

title: Europe live: Germany’s SPD set to reveal coalition agreement vote deal
snippets:
The deal, if approved, will be formally signed on Monday, paving the way for Friedrich Merz to be elected chancellor

Elsewhere, Swedish police said they have apprehended a suspect after a shooting in which three people were killed in the city of Uppsala on Tuesday, Reuters reported.

A large area was cordoned off in the centre of Uppsala, a university city 45 miles north of Stockholm, after witnesses described hearing multiple shots at about 5pm local time and seeing people running in different directions and hiding.

Continue reading...
titles: Europe live: Germany’s SPD set to reveal coalition agreement vote deal
summary: A deal set to be signed on Monday could lead to Friedrich Merz being elected as chancellor. In a separate event, Swedish police have arrested a suspect linked to a shooting in Uppsala, where three individuals were killed. The incident occurred in the city center, prompting a large area to be cordoned off after witnesses reported multiple shots and people fleeing the scene.
constructiveness_reason: The story provides useful information about political developments in Germany and a crime incident in Sweden. It informs readers about the potential political changes in Germany and increases awareness about safety issues in Sweden, but does not offer actionable insights or solutions.

title: Sectarian Clashes Erupt in Syria, Killing 12
snippets: The sectarian-tinged violence was directed at a suburb of the Syrian capital with a large population from the Druse minority. Local Druse leaders said they held the government responsible.

title: Aston Martin limits imports to US because of Trump tariffs
snippets:
Fellow carmakers Stellantis and Mercedes withdraw financial guidance for year over impact of trade war

The British sportscar maker Aston Martin is limiting imports to the US in the face of Donald Trump’s tariffs, while its counterparts Stellantis and Mercedes withdrew their financial guidance for the year, blaming the uncertainty around changing US policy on import levies.

Aston Martin, known for producing the cars driven by James Bond in the spy films, said it was “currently limiting imports to the US while leveraging the stock held by our US dealers”.

Continue reading...

Fellow carmakers Stellantis and Mercedes withdraw financial guidance for year over impact of trade war

The British sportscar maker Aston Martin is limiting imports to the US in the face of Donald Trump’s tariffs, while its counterparts Stellantis and Mercedes withdrew their financial guidance for the year, blaming the uncertainty around changing US policy on import levies.

Aston Martin, known for producing the cars driven by James Bond in the spy films, said it was “currently limiting imports to the US while leveraging the stock held by our US dealers”.

Continue reading...
titles: Aston Martin limits imports to US because of Trump tariffs
Aston Martin limits imports to US because of Trump tariffs
summary: Aston Martin is reducing its car imports to the US due to tariffs imposed by Donald Trump, utilizing its existing US dealer stock instead. Similarly, carmakers Stellantis and Mercedes have retracted their financial forecasts for the year, attributing this decision to the unpredictability of US trade policies and import taxes. This move reflects the broader automotive industry's struggle with the current trade environment.
constructiveness_reason: This article provides readers with actionable insights into how current US trade policies and import taxes are impacting the automotive industry. It also gives a deeper understanding of the decisions companies like Aston Martin, Stellantis, and Mercedes are making in response to these policies. However, it doesn't report on any solutions or improvements to the situation.

title: UBS posts profit beat but 'material risk' from Trump tariffs darkens outlook

titles: Forged in Fire: How Gamma-Ray Bursts Could Create the Universe’s Heaviest Elements

This theory challenges existing ideas on how these elements form and may explain unusual cosmic phenomena and metal traces found in Earth's crust.

title: Exceptional points boost sensitivity of surface acoustic wave sensors for gas detection
snippets: In an advance in microsensor technology, researchers have unveiled an ultra-sensitive gas detection method using surface acoustic wave (SAW) sensors enhanced by the physics of exceptional points (EPs). These EPs, phenomena from non-Hermitian systems where eigenvalues and eigenvectors converge, allow for amplified signal response.
titles: Exceptional points boost sensitivity of surface acoustic wave sensors for gas detection
summary: Researchers have developed a new, highly sensitive gas detection technology using surface acoustic wave (SAW) sensors, improved by incorporating exceptional points (EPs)—a concept from non-Hermitian physics where eigenvalues and eigenvectors meet. This advancement allows for significantly amplified signal responses, enhancing the sensors' ability to detect gases.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it reports on an innovative solution to improve gas detection technology. It provides actionable insights for those in the field and contributes to a deeper understanding of the subject for general readers. It also raises awareness about the application of non-Hermitian physics in practical technology.

title: Marker ink transforms into graphene-based electric circuit for low-cost sensors

titles: Marker ink transforms into graphene-based electric circuit for low-cost sensors
summary: Researchers have successfully created the first electric circuit using a marker and a laser beam, demonstrating that innovative and sustainable methods can generate electrical applications on various surfaces, including a coffee cup. This breakthrough indicates potential for diverse and accessible technological applications.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it reports on an innovative solution that has potential for diverse and accessible technological applications. It provides actionable insights and increases understanding of how sustainable methods can be used in creating electrical applications.

title: Watch the Moon Crown the World’s Largest Telescope in Stunning Image
snippets: Beneath a breathtaking full Moon, construction on the world’s largest optical and infrared telescope—the ELT—progresses in the Atacama Desert. Giant cranes sculpt its impressive structure while shimmering insulating panels shield it from the desert’s extremes. Captured at just the right moment by ESO’s Juan Beltrán, the image reveals not just the telescope’s grandeur, but a [...]
titles: Watch the Moon Crown the World’s Largest Telescope in Stunning Image
summary: A stunning image captured by ESO's Juan Beltrán shows the full Moon rising behind the Extremely Large Telescope (ELT) in the Atacama Desert, highlighting the ongoing construction of what will be the world's largest optical and infrared telescope. The photo showcases the telescope's impressive structure, enhanced by giant cranes and insulating panels designed to protect it from the harsh desert environment.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides a basic awareness about the construction of the world's largest optical and infrared telescope. While it doesn't offer in-depth insights, it does inform readers about the ongoing progress and the measures taken to protect the telescope from the harsh desert environment.
